lay.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: to put someone or something down carefully into a flat position
lay.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: He laid his hand on my shoulder.
They laid a wreath at the place where so many people died.
Lay the material flat on the table.
lay.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: if a bird, insect etc lays eggs, it produces them from its body
lay.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: The flies lay their eggs on decaying meat.
A cuckoo is able to lay in a range of different nests.
lay.translation[1].definitions[2].defini: to put the cloth, plates, knives, forks etc on a table, ready for a meal
lay.translation[1].definitions[2].exampl: As she spoke, she was laying him a place at the table.
lay.translation[1].definitions[3].defini: to make a statement, give information etc in an official or public way
lay.translation[1].definitions[3].exampl: Several proposals have been laid before the committee.
lay.translation[1].definitions[4].defini: to be in a position in which you are flat – some people consider this use to be incorrect
lay.translation[1].definitions[5].defini: to risk an amount of money on the result of a race, sports game etc
lay.translation[1].definitions[5].exampl: I’d lay money that he will go on to play for England.
She laid £50 on the favourite, Golden Boy.
She lays a lace cloth over the table
She lies a lace cloth over the table
Lay is also the past tense of lie
She was lying on her back
Let’s just lie here for a while
She was laying on her back
Let’s just lay here for a while
The past tense of lie is laid
She laid the baby in its cot
She lay the baby in its cot
lay.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: not trained or not knowing much about a particular profession or subject
lay.translation[2].definitions[1].defini: not in an official position in the church
